title: Stress: The Silent Killer

content: Perhaps one of the greatest life lessons is learning how to manage the silent killer: stress. Chronic stress has been linked to many illnesses including depression, anxiety, high blood pressure, and (surprise, surprise) fibromyalgia. Have you noticed how stress affects your chronic illness?

For me, where there’s increased stress, there’s likely a fibromyalgia flare looming. Not only can stress trigger a flare, but it can worsen existing symptoms including pain, fatigue, and sleep disorders. The link between stress and fibromyalgia truly feels like you’re being kicked while you’re down, and oftentimes I’m unsure which came first.

Living with a chronic illness can cause many stressors in your life, financially, emotionally, mentally, and physically. And when stress only exacerbates your chronic illness, you’re stuck in a vicious cycle. There’s no escaping chronic illness or stress in life, the only option is learning how to tame these beasts. So what does managing stress mean?

Managing stress takes a conscious and everyday effort, as most healthy habits need to be built. To lessen the impact of stress on fibromyalgia, make reducing stress a part of your daily routine- even on the days you don’t want to! Here are some of the ways I began introducing stress management into my daily life:

sections.heading: 1. Prioritize wellness.
content: Moving your body, eating nutritious foods, and practicing a healthy lifestyle can all support your body’s ability to regulate stress.
2. Find an outlet. It’s important to find healthy ways to release your stress, so try journaling, therapy, creative pursuits, or a hobby as a place to turn to when needed.

3. Create a routine. Don’t underestimate the power of a morning and night routine to help you recharge and rest from your days! Adding intentional structure to your day can help stabilize fluctuating stress hormones.
4. Breathe . A tale as old as time: Don’t forget to breathe! Breathwork and meditation can be one of the most powerful and easily accessible tools for managing your stress.
5. Supplement . There are many supplements you can turn to when you’re experiencing heightened stress, like l-theanine, CBD, or ashwagandha.

content: Whether or not you have a chronic illness, managing stress is a necessary life skill. Without even realizing it, stress may be taking a major toll on your body. There are various techniques to lower the stress hormone, cortisol. With some trial and error, you can find what works best for you. Emphasis on trial and error! After reading this blog, I want to encourage (and challenge) you to try one stress-reducing tactic for the next week. By the end of the week, hopefully, you’ve unlocked a new hack to relieve stress!
